docs.lead_paragraph: When the House of Representatives takes up legislation to define patients' rights this week, it will have a choice of three major bills that take very different approaches to regulating health insurance and health maintenance organizations. And that does not count a separate bill, passed by the Senate in July, on a vote largely along party lines.

headline.main: House Bills Diverge Over a Patient's Right to Sue

docs.abstract: Patients' rights legislation pending in House includes three major bills that take very different approaches to regulating health insurance and health maintenance organizations; all would create wide range of new Federal rights for patients, setting standards in field regulated mainly by states for 50 years; would guarantee coverage of emergency medical care, allow patients to appeal coverage decisions to independent board and insure that doctors could share information with patients; biggest difference involves relatively simple question of whether patients could sue HMO's to enforce their rights (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of Americans without health insurance rose last year by 833,000, to 44.3 million, despite a strong economy and a new law intended to provide coverage for children, the Census Bureau reported today. The ranks of the uninsured have grown by more than 4.5 million since President Clinton took office in 1993, promising health insurance for all Americans.

headline.main: MORE AMERICANS WERE UNINSURED IN 1998, U.S. SAYS

docs.abstract: Census Bureau reports that number of Americans without health insurance rose in 1998 by 833,000, to 44.3 million, despite strong economy and new law intended to provide coverage for children; says 16.3 percent of Americans lacked health insurance during year, highest number in decade; reports that in households with annual incomes of $50,000 or more, number of people without health insurance increased 1.7 million, to 12.2 million; ranks of uninsured have grown by more than 4.5 million since Pres Clinton took office in 1993, promising health insurance for all Americans; report comes three days before House debate on legislation defining range of new patients' rights; many Republicans, insurance companies and business groups argue that bill would raise premiums and contribute to further increases in number of uninsured; many Democrats dispute that; plight of uninsured is emerging as major issue in 2000 Presidential campaign, with former Democratic Senator Bill Bradley calling for renewed commitment to providing every American with access to coverage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton announced today new rules to protect children in a Federal health insurance program and asked voters to urge their lawmakers to pass a broad patients' bill of rights. ''Like many of you,'' Mr. Clinton said in his weekly radio address, ''I've been appalled by the tragic stories of men and women fighting for their lives, and at the same time forced to fight insurance companies focused only on the bottom line. If we work together, we've got the power to put patients first once again.''

headline.main: Clinton Urges Stronger Law Setting Rights For Patients

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton says Health and Human Services Department will propose rules to require health care providers participating in Federal health insurance program for children of low-income families to insure patients' access to specialists, emergency rooms and unbiased, timely appeals, radio speech; urges voters to press for broad patients' bill of rights law (M)9

docs.lead_paragraph: Alicia Marie Ballenger, a daughter of Jessie and Josephus B. Ballenger Jr. of Naugatuck, Conn., was married yesterday to Kevin Terrence Denson, the son of Catherine and Frederick L. Denson of Webster, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. J. Barrie Shepherd performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York. Mrs. Denson, who is 24 and a former model, is the administrative coordinator for the standards and practices department of MTV Networks, the cable television company in New York. She graduated magna cum laude from the University of Connecticut. Her father retired as an executive underwriter for the Hartford, the insurance company in Hartford. Her mother is a principal of Danbury (Conn.) High School.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bill Bradley's hope of broadening health insurance to 95 percent of Americans sounds great. If, as you suggest (editorial, Sept. 30), his proposal will again make health care a ''dominating issue'' in next year's elections, it's all to the good. But the debate is likely to miss the point.

headline.main: Bradley's Health Plan Has a Major Flaw

docs.lead_paragraph: Long Island's three eastern hospitals are negotiating a sponsorship arrangement with the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System that would allow them to use the system's vast array of medical and support services. ''One of the big advantages of this kind of arrangement is that a large network of health providers can get better contractual agreements from insurance companies and suppliers,'' said Carol Hauptman, the system's vice president of community relations.
docs.abstract: Peconic Health Corp moves toward finalizing agreement with North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System that would allow Southampton Hospital, Central Suffolk Hospital and Eastern Long Island Hospital to use North Shore's vast array of medical and support services (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Opening its new term on Monday, the Supreme Court returns from a three-month recess to a docket that places the Justices squarely in the midst of some of the country's most passionate debates, from health care to campaign finance to Government aid to religious schools. In addition, the Court will continue its re-examination of the boundary between Federal authority and state sovereignty, taking up new cases that move the federalism battleground into the arena of civil rights legislation, where the stakes are higher than ever.
docs.abstract: Supreme Court is set to begin new term; has accepted 15 new cases in last three weeks, bringing total to 44 and filing its argument calendar through Jan; roundup of issues before Court (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: My concern with Bill Bradley's health plan is that it has no provisions to make health insurance mandatory, and therefore we will likely continue to have millions of the uninsured (editorial, Sept. 30). In addition to the low-income group, many employed adults do not carry any health insurance, even though they can afford it. They are healthy, have a low risk of becoming seriously ill and feel that the money is better spent on other things.

headline.main: Bradley's Health Plan Has a Major Flaw

docs.lead_paragraph: If there is a model for an effective way to handle experimental procedures, it is the world of pediatric cancer. In that arena, most doctors refuse to offer such treatments outside clinical trials, insurance companies usually pick up the tab and experimental procedures are tested quickly, before they reach the marketplace. The result is that the procedures that work are adopted widely; those that do not are quickly abandoned.

headline.main: In Pediatrics, a Lesson in Making Use of Experimental Procedures

docs.abstract: Pediatric cancer world offers model for effective way to handle experimental procedures; most doctors refuse to offer pediatric treatments outside clinical trials, insurance companies usually pay bills and experimental procedures are tested rapidly, before they reach marketplace; pediatric oncologists have organized selves into two major consortiums that enroll virtually every child in clinical trial (M)
